stem: The nurse is performing a sterile wound irrigation. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Irrigate the wound from the cleanest area to the dirtiest (top to bottom) with constant pressure.
Perform hand hygiene and don sterile gloves.
Perform hand hygiene and don clean gloves to remove the old dressing.
Pat the surrounding skin dry with sterile gauze.
Fill a 35-mL syringe with sterile irrigation solution and attach a 19-gauge angiocatheter.

rationale.correct: Wound irrigation requires mechanical force and asepsis. (1) Dressing removal is clean. (2) Irrigation is sterile. (3) A 35-mL syringe and 19-g needle provide the ideal pressure (8 psi) to remove debris without damaging granulation tissue. (4) Clean-to-dirty (Gravity workflow) prevents cross-contamination. (5) Drying prevent skin maceration.
rationale.incorrect: Irrigating from the bottom up is incorrect as gravity will wash contaminants into the clean area.
clinicalPearls: The objective of irrigation is to achieve 4 to 15 psi of pressure. Excessive pressure can push bacteria deeper into the tissue.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that you don't use a 'sharp' needle for irrigation; you use an 'angiocatheter' (the plastic tip) to avoid accidental injury.

reviewUnits.heading: Wound Care: Debridement and Irrigation
reviewUnits.body: Nurses assess for tunneling and undermining before irrigation. Document the type of drainage (serous, purulent) and the client's tolerance.
